orchestable.title: Orchestable
orchestable.tagLine: Multi-touch Orchestra (HCI, Computer Graphics, Image & Audio Processing)
orchestable.description:
What is Orchestable?

Orchestable is a system which provides a digital multi-touch interface to a group of people for playing multiple musical instruments simultaneously on the same multi-touch screen. The user can play more than one musical instrument simultaneously with a more realistic user interface, broader accessibility and flexibility than those already existing. There are 4 different instruments available to choose from: Piano, Octapad, Congos and Drums.

Final Setup

The hardware of the project was implemented using a simple IR Camera, Plain Glass sheet, Wooden Table and a Short-throw Projector. Later, I had interfaced this project with the project of one of my colleague who had developed a sound processing module using MAX/MSP.

The Process

One day, I was using a music application GarageBand on iPad and I thought why we can only play one instrument, why not multiple instruments simultaneously?

After doing some Secondary Research, I found that people are trying to play multiple instrument in groups using this application but using multiple devices. I further searched for a good enough multi-touch application which allow users to play simultaneously on the same device but found nothing. So, I decided to create one myself. Orchestable is a touch device using which a group of people can play different (or same) music instruments simultaneously on the same device. The cost for the entire setup was $550 not including a computer for running the software on.

The Process

Secondary Research

After doing some research online, I came up with few design constraints:

  • The touch screen should be big enough for a group of people to interact simultaneously.
  • It has to be a low cost device to make it affordable.
  • User should be able to dismantle the setup in order to move it around.
  • The process of assembling the setup should be fairly easy to make it less time consuming.

Since, a big capacitive touch screens was too costly, I began to research low cost methods of making a touch screen myself. I found few methods to build infrared based touch screens.

Prototyping

I selected two technology to test them on a prototype of the final table design: Rear Diffused Illumination(RDI) and Front Diffused illumination(FDI). The rationales behind selecting these two optical technology were:

  • the cheapest hardware solutions among all six of them
  • also reasonably accurate compared to technology like LED Light Plane
  • the most accurate and effective is Frustated Internal Reflection but it is also the costliest one
  • a FDI and RDI setup can be put together using simpler tools like "light bulb" for IR emission, etc.

The prototype consists of .

The main problem of playing a percussion instrument is the measure of pressure and the frequency by which the user is hitting the pads. To address the pressure problem I am developing a concept for measuring the pressure on such glass surface.

technology.list: Secondary Research, Rapid Prototyping
J2SE1.6, MT4J, CCV, JOGL, MinimLibs, Eclipse
A wooden table, normal webcam(Converted to IR), ShortThrow Projector, Transparent Glass Sheet, Butter Paper

toothgloss.title: ToothGloss
toothgloss.description:
What is Toothgloss?

ToothGloss is an advanced interdental cleaning system, to be used as a replacement, or supplement to traditional flossing. ToothGloss includes advanced technology gum-like Gloss sticks within a SmartBox, whose interactive digital screen empowers the users to set goals and schedules that work for their lives.

The goal of this product is to make the activity of interdental cleaning fit better within people’s lives, allowing them to use the product regularly to improve their dental health.

How we started..

We started with forming a problem statement.

The modern day medical system has learned what it takes to maintain healthy teeth throughout one’s lifetime, and created technology to enable users to act towards this endeavor. Yet, the rate of preventable oral disease remains high, even among highly educated populations with access to medical tools and expertise. What can be done to decrease these disease rates?

Identifying the problem..

USER RESEARCH

With the problem statement in mind we decided to conduct over user research

Secondary Research

Questionnaire

Armed with a narrowed focus on interdental cleaning, it was time to consult the users about their practices at home, so we created a Questionnaire using SurveyGizmo

Semi-Structured Interviews

These were performed by giving the interviewee the Questionnaire to understand where they fall in line with our survey participants, and then asking more specific questions about their feelings towards and motivations regarding their dental hygiene practices. These conversations were open-ended and only prompted when needed, allowing the user to provide the most unbiased information.

Result

Our research methods showed that the design requirements are as follows. The design should:

  • be portable
  • be quick to use and/or hands-free to allow multitasking
  • show before and after results or provide other immediate feedback
  • inform the user of health risks
  • remind the user to perform interdental cleaning
  • have neutral taste and be pain free

Our Design Question

How can we improve the frequency and quality of user-performed interdental cleaning among working-age adults?

  • Frequency and quality – many people do currently perform interdental cleaning, however irregularly, and often poorly.
  • User-performed – research indicated the state of daily care of the teeth had more long term effect on oral health than the care that occurs at biannual visits to dental health professionals.
  • Working-age – for the purposes of this study, this was defined as ages 16 through 60, encompassing the time when the mouth has fully matured up to the health changes of later life.

The next step..

IDEATION

Suction Wand

The SuctionWand is perhaps the most familiar dental product as a comparable suction device is currently used in dental offices and it looks similar to an electric toothbrush or Waterpik®. The user manually moves the wand around their mouth while it provides suction to remove the plaque around and in between the teeth. The SuctionWand can also deliver ultrasonic pulses to loosen plaque that may be too dried on for the vacuum to remove. The suction feature is messfree since no postcleaning spitting is required, allowing it to be used anywhere. The device only uses suction where plaque is detected, speeding up the process. When plaque is found, the device will beep at the user as a warning and then automatically begin suction, providing immediate feedback that plaque has been removed.

These results are recorded and uploaded to an app where the user can also set goals and get reminders via text message. The app shows the potential oral health risks of not using the SuctionWand, and as additional motivation to utilize the device regularly, the users’ results are uploaded to their dentists’ leaderboard where they can compete with other patients. For users who are not smartphone enabled, a simple alarm reminder can be set on the device using small dials. The SuctionWand is a onehanded device allowing for a semimultitasking experience, but it is fast and painfree (except maybe for a few users with very sensitive teeth), with the added socialmedia motivational component. The product is also reusable, making it more expensive up front, but longerlasting and less wasteful. It is also very small and light for portability. The wand’s vacuum core will need to be emptied infrequently, and the device notifies the user via a series of beeps when this needs to be performed.

ToothGloss

ToothGloss is gum that flosses. Less viscous and more sticky than typical chewing gum, it flows between and around the teeth, grabbing the plaque. Upon spitting out the gum, the user can see the removed items stuck in the substance, giving immediate results. ToothGloss meets our design requirements of being portable and handsfree. It is cheap and disposable and also comes in different flavors. Its case has a slot for each day of the month, visually reminding the consumer to use the product. The reusable case provides a touchscreen interface where the user can set reminders and goals of what they would like accomplish by their next dental visit. The case also displays the risks that are avoided by using ToothGloss. This highertech case would be an investment upon beginning the using of the Glossing system, but is only purchased once. While gum is a familiar object, it is not made for every type of user. Those with temporomandibular joint disorder (TMJ), cannot chew gum frequently.

FlossBots

FlossBots are microscopic robots contained within a userfriendly liquid medium. Using mass spectrometertype technology, they seek out the plaque in between and around the users’ teeth, and then target those locations for scrubbingstyle cleaning. Nanobots are a budding technology currently being researched and developed as a less invasive way to pinpoint problems in human health. Delivery as a liquid enables the user flexibility of where to use the product; in their home or on the go. Interdental cleaning is made simple, efficient, and portable, and can come in different flavors for a variety of palates. Unlike floss, FlossBots is painfree and handsfree, allowing the user to multitask. Results are confirmed when the user spits out the cleaner; removed plaque can be viewed as a different color in the liquid. If spit out, the nanobots are removed; if the user is not in a situation where this is possible, such as the car, they are safe to swallow, seamlessly exiting the body with other nondigestibles.

Molding our ideas..

PROTOTYPING

We chose to do a prototype of the ToothGloss by creating a low-tech box (cardboard, hot glue, and springs) with a digital interface (JustInMind on cell phone). This allowed us to prototype five out of six of our design criteria, represented in bold below. In the short time flow of this project we were unable to obtain color changing gum to simulate plaque detection, however we were able to create a small and light portable box containing pain-free, taste optional (mint in this case), hands-free gum. The box’s screen interface allows the user to set goals and reminders and display informational health tips.

Hardware Prototype


Software Prototype


Finally..

USABILITY TESTING

The evaluations were performed in the “wild” or uncontrolled environment of the HUB second floor. After a brief introduction to the purpose and situation of use of our system, the testers went through the tasks listed on page three.

The users found a variety of bugs and places for improvement, as fully catalogued in the Design Iterations section on page four. Some particularly notable findings: one user was unfamiliar with flossing (cultural difference) and such we were solving a problem he did not have and gave him a little extra introduction to the situation. Two of the users were unaware that the alarm sound was in-fact meant for them, an apparent hazard of Wizard-of-Oz features in an uncontrolled environment. Minor tweaks were made to the interface between users, so they had slightly different experiences. Between the first and second tests we changed the screen resolution (switched phones) for a better user experience, and between the second and third tests we made some changes to the box labelling, adding a title and moving the day-by-day tickmarks per user suggestion.

Evaluation Tasks

Please read this paragraph out loud to become comfortable with narrating your thoughts for us:

ToothGloss is an advanced flossing system. The futuristic gum can target and clean plaque between the teeth without the need for traditional flossing. This is an early prototype. Please complete the tasks below, talking aloud as you go. It is helpful to us if you narrate your thoughts, good, bad, weird etc during the evaluation.

  • Add a goal to gloss weekdays at 7am.
  • Add a reminder for 7am on weekdays.
  • Add another goal to gloss on weekends.
  • Set a reminder for Saturday at 3pm.
  • Review the risks of not flossing.
  • When your weekend alarm goes off, take out a piece of advanced technology gloss gum.
  • Approximate which day’s gum you selected. Which day of which week was it?
  • Find out more information about one of the risks.

Post-Evaluation Questionnaire

  • When performing the ToothGloss tasks, was anything confusing?
  • When working with the interface, did ToothGloss do what you expected?
  • What features did you like?
  • What features need improvement or were missing?
  • Would such a product motivate you to floss more?

technology.list: SurveyGizmo, Justinmind, Paper, Hot-glue, Spring, Cardboard, Smartphone, Gums, WoOz, Surveys, User Interview, Usability testing in Wild

smart-touchpad.title: Smart Touchpad
smart-touchpad.description:
What is Smart Touchpad?

Using Smart Touchpad, a user can use a paper surface as a touch pad and his finger or any pointed/convex object as stylus to write or draw.

How it works?

The software captures the user interaction with the paper using a web camera. The images are processed to identify if user has touched the paper surface and the location of the touch. In order to locate the touch location, the tool uses an advanced finger tip detection algorithm. A rectangle drawn on paper for perspective identification.

technology.list: C#, EmguCV, Visual Studio, Webca

hollywood-stars.title: Hollywood Stars
hollywood-stars.tagLine: Enabling Exploration and Trend Examination within the Oscar Award Dataset
hollywood-stars.description:
Indentifying users..

User Research

Data Collection

To get the data related to Oscar movies that we needed, we used the official Academy Award database, as it is the most trusted source for Oscar related data. To collect other details of the movies in that list, we chose to use IMDb and Rotten Tomatoes. Both sources have an extension database and carry high credibility among the audience as information sources.

To start, we downloaded the list of movies from the Academy Award database, and generated an ID number for every movie. This gave us a record for 8832 movies in the dataset. Using an ID for each would help to ease the merging process later on when we had additional data. Afterwards, we started collecting data from IMDb using a free web service API, OMDb. This API allows input for name and year of the movie, and provides additional details about that movie (if any record exists) in JSON format. Once we had the JSON data for all of the movies, we used a text editor (we chose Sublime Text) to reformat it. From here, we used OpenRefine to convert the data into tabular format, which is readable in Excel. This gave us the in-depth movie details data, which was then merged with the Oscar movie dataset using a custom Excel macro coded in Visual Basic. Later, we extracted Rotten Tomatoes’ data for their critics’ and users’ ratings. For this purpose, we used Rotten Tomatoes’ web API interface, and wrote a Python script to get the data in JSON format. We then merged it with the Oscar dataset following almost the same process as for the previous data merges.

With big data set came Big Problems!

Due to the inconsistent naming convention of IMDb, we had to manually search for approximately 1200 movies on the IMDb site in order to either correct the name or the movie release year, as many times Oscar nomination year and release year are different. Additionally, we used OpenRefine to correct any typos in the titles. Since many of our dimensions have multiple values, we were not able to use them for anything in Tableau other than as a filter using a calculated field and custom parameters. This created an issue for us in exploring our data. We addressed this by creating a natural join between the list of genre and the movie list, thus allowing us to use the genre field as a dimension that can be used in a graph. This would enable us to provide better data filtration methods for an end user.

Though we eventually created a cohesive data set suitable for our purposes, we did experience some challenges. One of our biggest challenges in making meaning of this data was that the majority of the values were nominal data. This left us with few quantitative values that could be used for analysis. Fortunately, some of the nominal fields we had to work with make meaningful differences with regards to movie audiences, especially genre. One way we considered dealing with this challenge was to take the plot text data and classify each movie into a story type. The plan was to make this a filter in the data, so that users see comparisons between not only a movie’s genre, but a movie’s mood or plot as well. Ultimately, we discovered this to be a larger undertaking than would be worth undertaking, given the short time frame, and likely much more difficult than we would be prepared for as well. Previous research had been attempted using a machine learning algorithm and custom scripts to classify movies into strict genres using the plot synopsis found in IMDb. Unfortunately, this approach yielded results of only 12% accuracy (Tanenbaum, p6.) A possible reason for this is that most movies can accompany more than one genre type, which is also an issue we discovered within our dataset. For this reason, we decided to abandon this as a possible approach.

Playing with data

technology.list: Tableau, Sublime, Excel, OpenRefine, Python, OMDb REST API, Rotten Tomatoes REST AP

car-parking.title: Automated Car-Parking
car-parking.description:
Parking has always been a problem. It takes a lot of time to park a vehicle: navigating through the parking complex and finding an empty spot, then parking your vehicle and walk back to your destination. To solve this issue, we developed an automated parking system using which a user can leave his/her car at the entrance of the parking complex and the car will automatically park itself.

What does it do?

The car is equiped with an automated parking system which frees the user from all the problems related to parking. After the user leaves his car at the entrance, the car will autmatically traverse through the parking lot to find an empty space for parking. Upon finding an empty slot, it will park itself in the slot through an automated driving mechanism built inside the car.

How it works?

The system is equiped with an AT-Mega 8051 micro-controller and 3 IR sensors. Using these sensors the micro-controller checks for obtracles in the front, on the left and on the right.

technology.list: AT-Mega 8051, a development board, 16x2 LCD, 2 motors, 3 IR Emitters, 3 IR Receivers

sunglass-trial.title: Sunglass Trial
sunglass-trial.tagLine: Human-Computer Interaction, Computer Graphics, Augmented Reality
sunglass-trial.description:
Using Sunglass Trial a user can try out various sunglasses/prescription glasses virtually using an augmented reality technology in real time. The tool identifies pose of the user's face and augment a virtual 3D model of the selected sunglass onto the face.

The tool also has another module to create the 3D models of the eye wear using 2D images the physical glasses. This is an automated process which involves taking 2D pictures of the eye wear using a camera and afterwards processing it to construct a 3D model precisely with texture.

technology.list: C++, OpenCV, Visual Studio, Webca

real-time-ray-tracing.title: RealTime RayTracing
real-time-ray-tracing.description:
A real time ray tracing using openGL and openCL for parallel GPU programming. This ray tracer implements reflection with some additional tuning features like Procedural Textures using Perlin Noise, Blinn-Phong, Point light source, Cude Map, Gamma Reduction, Exposure and anti-aliasing. Currently the shapes supported by the ray tracer are Spheres, Plane, Infinite Plane, and cube. Triangles is under development.

The ray tracer was tested on NVIDIA GTX 560M and the fps we are getting on it is 32frames/sec.
real-time-ray-tracing.technology: Developed using C/C++, OpenGL, Cuda, OpenCL

motif-extraction.title: Motif Extraction
motif-extraction.description:
Motif is an element of a pattern, image or part of one, or theme. A motif may be repeated in
    a design or composition, often many times, or may just occur once in a work. A motif may be an element
    in the iconography of a particular subject or type of subject that is seen in other work.

content-based-image-retrieval.title: Content Based Image Retrieval
content-based-image-retrieval.description:
This project aimed at developing a image search system, combining various CBIR technology to take advantages of each one in order to minimize the negative effects/limitations of other approaches.

Our project goal is to retrieve images which are similar and not exactly same. Most of current work eg: tineye.com has been done to retrieve exactly similar images from the dataset. We aim a bit different and target the segments instead of complete image. The extraction process has been on the basis of three domains Shape, Texture and Colour. The thresholds for these parameters would depend upon the type of image inputted for the search. We aim to make retrieval fast and hence a dynamic clustring algorithm has been implemented to get results faster and work over the machine learning algorithm so that system learns from users is in progress.
content-based-image-retrieval.technology: Developed using C/C++, BigData concepts like Map-Reduce, Distributed data

fractal-image-compression.title: Fractal Image Compression
fractal-image-compression.description:
The project intends to use "equal division load" balancing algorithm to design parallel
    fractal coding algorithm and implement the Fractal Image Compression. "Equal division load" balancing
    algorithm distributes computation tasks to all processors equally. Load on server is divided into
    smaller tasks based on all power of nodes on network, and then these smaller tasks are sent to
    corresponding nodes to process. Analysis has shown that such algorithms greatly reduce the computation
    task execution time.
fractal-image-compression.technology: Developing using J2SE 1.6.0_22 on Eclipse Indigo 3.7

gr-make.title: GrMake
gr-make.description:
GrMake is a cross platform open-source tool developed to provide user with a functionality
    to view a graph in 3d space from an input file written using DOT language. The graph in 3d will be drawn
    such that no edge intersect each other. The user have full flexibility to implement his/her own modules
    for any of the functionality of the tool.

technology.list: JAVA (J2SE, J2EE), Eclipse Indigo 3.7, RAD (Rapid Application Developer), DB2, XM

dos-roq-voip.title: Study of Effect of DoS and RoQ on VOIP Traffic
dos-roq-voip.description: We are investigated the effect of these attacks on the QoS sensitive real time UDP traffic like VoIP. The attack potency formula was formulated in our work to observe the detrimental effect of the attack on the VoIP traffic. We are studying the effect of the attack flow on three QoS parameters of a VoIP flow, namely, the delay, the jitter, and the packet loss.

aco-routing-in-nirgam-simulator.title: ACO Routing in NIRGAM simulator
aco-routing-in-nirgam-simulator.description:
ACO Routing in NIRGAM simulator (A NoC Interconnect Routing and Application Modeling). NIRGAM Simulator is a research project of MNIT, Jaipur for developing a discrete event, cycle accurate simulator targeted at Network on Chip (NoC) research. The project is carried under the supervision of Prof. M.S. Gaur, Former HOD, Department of Computer Science and Engineering, MNIT, Jaipur.

ACO routing is known to be capable of adapting to the necessary environmental conditions. These condition can be varied to get a optimized route in the current environmental conditions. The task assigned to me was to implement the ACO routing in NIRGAM simulator to find the optimum route with shorter route length and minimal power consumption over the network. The routing implemented was also able to adjust in order to minimize the congestion. The algorithm implemented was generic w.r.t. the topology of the network. The project was completed under the guidance of Prof. M.S. Gaur.
